Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Novel Field Drug Test System for Law Enforcement
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to improve law enforcement (LE) effectiveness in battling the illegal drug epidemic in the U.S. Death rates related to drug use have been increasing yearly and exceeded 72,000 Americans in 2017. To control this epidemic, the President?s 2019 Budget Request called for $30B in federal funding to combat illegal drug use, presenting a commercial opportunity to disrupt the existing market for conventional color test kits and Raman-based testing systems. Numerous interviews conducted with LE and forensic supply resellers demonstrate a readiness to adopt a new technology to replace drug test kits currently in use. This novel drug test system will improve the accuracy, reliability, ease of use, safety, and affordability of field drug identification and permit field use data analysis, which will help remove dangerous drugs from the streets. This innovation will also enhance the understanding of the chemical and photoluminescent properties of narcotic drugs reacting with various drug-indicator materials such as copper(I) iodide and validate the use of such information to identify suspected drugs. This is a wireless technology for the LE market sector, with the potential to eventually expand into the medical diagnostics and environmental analysis markets.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a novel system for on-site field drug testing for LE. Conventional chemical-based color tests are outdated and highly flawed, causing issues for end users and the rest of the drug enforcement ecosystem. These issues include false positive drug tests and the lack of ability to identify new drugs that are introduced into U.S. communities each year. Superior testing methods such as handheld Raman devices are too expensive for LE agencies to widely adopt, thus a low-cost technologically-innovative solution is necessary. This innovation leverages photoluminescence spectroscopy in four main components: a handheld spectrometer, a drug-sampling device, a mobile app with a matching algorithm and access to a cloud database of reference drug standards. The goal of this phase I project is to achieve a high-fidelity Minimum Viable Product drug testing system. The investigation of alternative fluorescent drug-indicators is anticipated to result in novel methods for drug identification with high selectivity and sensitivity. These methods will be implemented into a drug-sampling device. As a part of software and hardware optimization, beta testers within LE will help identify system shortcomings and provide input to develop enhancements for usability and ergonomics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a result of this NSF SBIR Phase I award, IDEM, LLC developed a prototype drug testing system that will help law enforcement combat the illegal drug epidemic. Current methods of field drug testing for police officers are highly flawed and do not provide law enforcement agencies with data that can be used to actually reduce the amount of dangerous drugs that enter into our communities. These methods have been in use for decades and fail to evolve technologically to keep up with the ever-changing illegal drug environment. IDEM's innovation that was developed leverages a proprietary handheld fluorescence spectrometer to analyze a drug sample collected at the tip of a drug sampling pen. The IDEM mobile app is then used to capture an image of the sample and use it to find a data match in IDEM's reference drug database. This necessary simplification of the field drug testing process eliminates common human errors and minimizes false results that are experienced by police officers using the traditional methods. The law enforcement community has a need for better tools for drug testing that are easy-to-use, more accurate, safe to use, and adaptable to the always-changing illegal drug market. IDEM's prototype drug testing system brings law enforcement agencies a step closer to a final solution that addresses their dire needs, and furthermore, will provide them with a new tool that can identify drug signatures and analyze illegal drug distribution within their respective communities. With annual drug overdose death tolls of approximately 70 thousand people in each of the last few years, U.S. law enforcement must swiftly adopt and implement new and innovative approaches to bring these numbers down. In an era in which new technology is frequently being introduced to consumers and enterprise companies to help resolve their problems, there has been an insufficient amount of research and development directed toward providing law enforcement with an affordable tool that will help resolve a huge societal issue (drug abuse and addiction) that affects millions of American people and families everyday. IDEM intends to provide the nation's law enforcement community with this hardware and software combination to significantly curb the epidemic. 

This project period resulted in the development of prototype hardware and software components, working alongside a small hardware engineering firm and small software development firm. The spectrometer was designed to have a proprietary optical path that eliminates the need for lenses and monochromators, which has never been achieved in a fluorescence spectrometer. The drug sampling pen leverages the design of a marker, and offers a method of sample collection that helps the law enforcement user avoid making dermal contact with potentially hazardous drugs like fentanyl. The software component that was developed consists of a mobile app the leverages cloud technologies to access a reference drug database to ultimately provide even the most novice of law enforcement users the capability to accurately identify illegal drugs within seconds. With the help of feedback from multiple narcotics units, IDEM included features on the prototype that addressed the target end user's needs.
